On Monday, preparing for his proposal on international organization,
Dr Shotwell classed Germany as a
nation of militant anarchy with war
as the sovereign power. In the same
relation he classed United States as
being
potentially
a
philosphical
anarchist.
Dr Shotwell described a national
state as an organization that is built
upon a thousand years of loyalty and
another thousand years of its citizenry's realization or assumption of
it perfectness. In other words its
citizens believe their government is
far advanced as is possible for
it to be. Adolf Hitler is content to
have his people believe this and would
like to have everyone have this belief in his state. This will be his
peace.
"At present no one is in a position," said Dr Shotwell, "We are just
If anarchy should come, a new set
of affairs would be necessary or the
world would be lost as a civilization, said Dr Shotwell, "We are just
beginning to be civilized and hardly
that."
In addition to the militant anarchist (Germany), there is the
philosophical anarchist ,in which
class the United States falls. "We
wish to be left alone by everyone.
Leave things as they are and be an
isolationist in all things. This theory
is different from that of neutrality.
Neutrality defends the right of the
neutral whereas the isolationist favors the right of no war for the nation as a whole. Thus far the United
States has no arbitration treaties
but does have agreements, wiith nations whom she likes, for reference
of dispute to the Senate .
"Speaking of disputes, that brings
us to the present neutrality debate.
Our neutrality now is very costly.

'Hullabaloo' staff
to start subscription
drive Monday
The drive for 100 per cent senior
subscription to the Hullabaloo for
1940 will start rolling on Monday,
when every senior will be approached
by a staff member.
According to Alan M. Hecht, senior
editor, " it is an absolute necessity
that we get complete Senior support
this year, so as to enable us to produce a yearbook worthy of the class
of 1940. The Hullabaloo is a publication mainly for the senior class, and
therefore if the seniors want a lasting memory of their college days it
is up to them to give the Hullabaloo
complete cooperation."
Assignments for write-ups were
given out yesterday at the weekly
staff meeting. Work on the book is
already under way, and it will probably appear several weeks earlier
than in previous years. Individual
photographs of fraternity members
will be eliminated, and group frat
photos will take their place. This
move it is hoped, will obviate much of
the confusion that featured the picture-taking of last year's book, and
thus make possible a smoother production schedule.
Jay students wishing to work on
the staff have an opportunity this
year. There are many vacant spots
to be filled, those desirious of trying
out should come to the office in the
basement of Levering hall any day.

Contacted: Glenn Miller

Wanted: A columnist
The NEWS-LETTER wants another columnist. Since Buddy
Macht left last year, taking his
Pot Pourri with him, there' been
nothing like it in the paper.
Buddy's column had a touch of
philosophy and more than a little
humor and criticism; but above
all it rested on personality. He
included anything he thought
worth-while. Sometimes Patsy,
his dog, got twice as much space
as the latest novel, but it all came
out right.
If you think you can write
such a column, get in touch with
J C Handlesman, P 0 Box 396.

Big doings come from the BSA
again this week as Don Kirkwood,
chairman, releases plans for a
Thanksgiving "name-band" dance.
Foremost among the bands contacted
and most likely to be hired is Al
Donahue's orchestra, currently featured in the Rainbow room.
In their quest of big name talent
the board repeated their action of
last year as they contacted all the
bands who could possibly be obtained.
Although no definite statment was
obtained, it was believed that Kirkwood had contacted Glenn Miller, one
of the nation's current swing favorites who played here last year. Miller
will be in the East during Thanksgiving week but the possibilities of
signing him are slim since several
movie houses are at present bidding
,for his talent.
Donahue and his society band as
they are called, are regularly featured
in the Rainbow room, and have made
few tours in the past three years.
If he plays at Hopkins it will be during a Thanksgiving trip on which he
will perfrom at several Northern
schools. Princeton and Harvard are
believed to have already signed him.
Donahue has a radio program by
virtue of which he has become popular throughout the East. His band
features clarinets.
Newly elected class presidents will
take their positions on the BSA this
week and will have a voice in the
selection of the Thanksgiving band.
Last week's dance at Levering is
reported by Kirkwood as a "financial
and social" success.

Second sex
discussion slated
The second sex discussion in which
Goucher college and Hopkins' students will participate will be held at
4:00 pm at Levering hall next Thursday. This discussion is a follow-up of
Mrs Grace Sloan Overton's lecture
of last week. Bill Hammaker will be
in charge of a discussion in which
both Goucher and Hopkins' students
will participate. The open discussion
will re-votive around the practical
aspects of sex relations.
Last week Mrs Overton spoke on
"Relationship of Men and Women in
Preparation for Marriage." "Wistful
sophistication is a term which may
be applied very aptly to our •present
generation," stated Mrs. Overton. Her
general theme was romantic love and
what it implies in conduct.

Students expecting to apply for
admission to any medical college by
next fall must take the medical
college aptitude test, the Registrar's
office announced recently.
This examination has been adopted
by the American association of Medical school as a means of determining
whether or not a student is qualified
to continue in medicine, and a passing mark is prerequisite to entrance
in a medical course. The test is designed to measure the student's ability to learn, his scientific background
and present store of information.
Also tested is the accuracy with
which the applicant can draw conclusions from a set of given data.
Application to take the exam must
be made immediately at room 18,
Remsen hall. The test will be given
for only this year on November
28 at 3:00 p m, in Remsen 101. A
fee of one dollar will be charged for
the examination.

Sheehy opens
religious series
At 8:15 last Monday evening, Rev
Dr Maurice S Sheehy, head of the
department of Religious Education,
Catholic University of America, gave
the first of a series of lectures on the
theme "Points of Difference Between
My Group and Others." ,Dr Sheehy
pointed out the main distinguishing
features of the Catholic doctrine, and
went on to explain a few of the major
problems which his church is facing
at present.
Dr Sheehy explained that through
a common bond based on the
Petronian doctrines, the church has
an international untiy on an authoritarian basis.
However, the system of administration does not preclude a certain
plasticity of views, contrary to common belief.
(Continued on Page 4)

Trustees to act on Shriver,
Vincent bequests Monday
Vincent
Exact terms of the will of Dr John
Martin Vincent, professor in the
social science department for 35
years and professor emeritus of that
department for 14 years, were received by the university last Monday.
Although the definite value of the
portion of the estate willed to the
university is, as yet, undetermined,
it is expected to yield $1,000,000. The
remainder of the estate has been
left by the late Dr Vincent to his
relatives and friends.
Dr Vincent's donation is the largest
ever received by a social science
department.
The bequest has been made to the
university without any legal demands
upon its disbursement. However, it
was the wish of Dr Vincent, according to his will, that the money be
used in the history department.
Members of the Board of Trustees
will meet Monday in one of their
three annual meetings. It is expected
that a decision will be reached at this
meeting as to the use of the bequest.

Shriver
Action on the Alfred Jenkins
Shriver bequest for the establishment
of a lecture hall with murals of the
Shriver family and Baltimore beauties will be taken Monday at the
meeting of the Board of Trustees, it
has been announced.
Although the exact amount of the
bequest is not known, an estimate
places the amount the Hopkins will
receive at approximately $650,000.
Under the donor's provisions, however, if the Board does not decide
within a six months period, the sum
will be offered in turn to Loyola and
Goucher.
The need for more elaborate lecture facilities has been emphasized
by the inconveniences accompanying
the talks of recent speakers here.
This need was especially felt at
the first of Dr James T Shotwell's
addresses at the Myer Katz Memorial Lectures. Because of the large
attendance, latecomers were forced
to stand outside the doors in Latrobe
hall, unable to hear.

FRIDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1939

It's pleasant to be able to
do other than criticize the
Barnstormers for a change.
We're never really had anything against the greasepaint lads, but matters of
policy and misunderstanding have often been bones of contention between us.
However, it looks as though there's s9mething really
swell in the offing.

We Take
It All
Back

First, the Club plans two productions this year—
although, they hasten to assure us, the idea is all
theirs, completely original. Second, it appears that
the Club has sure-pop, can't-miss irons in the fire, inthe form of two original or semi-original student (at
last!) plays.
We were highly flattered in being invited to the
preview of the first the other night. Frankly, we left
highly excited. We're not sure as to how much we're
at liberty to divulge; suffice to say that the play is a
hybrid original-rewrite by the Messrs Agrin and Victaroff of an exciting old. theme.
As we were told, a play depends on either dialogue
or action for effect. Since the 'Stormers themselves
(with our heartiest concurrence) admit a dearth of
material to carry the former, they've concentrated on
action. And there's action a-plenty.
Our contention has always been that the Hopkins
wants one of two things from the Club—a rollicking,
slapsticky farce, or a good student play. The subject
matter of the latter is unimportant—the vital thing is
that if it is from a student ,and is good, it will engross
students. And, assuming that the 'Stormers are anxious to gain campus goodwill, they would adhere to
these precepts and abstain from selfish half-baked
flings at art. Well, the play seems to fit the qualifications of our good student play.
We understand farther that our own "Toy" Swerdloff has submitted a slaphappy college farce which is
being considered for a second show. It never rains
but it pours! Should this go through, the Club will
be giving the campus the biggest time any of us here
now can remember.
Maybe we're a little premature with all this, but
we feel like saying right now, "Come back home,
boys, all is forgiven!"
In May, 1939 the Hopkins student body tramped
to the polls and elected a
Student council pledged by
platform (except for those
few who deemed posting
of platforms beneath them
—and got away with it) to abolish compulsory assemblies. At the beginning of October 1939, the
Council held its first assembly—compulsory. An assembly committee was set up to investigate and settle
the problem once and for all. And now at the end
of October we're back where we were in February 1939.
Time marches back!

Same
Old
Stalemate

We refrained from editorial comment on the first
compulsory assembly at the time because we thought
there were certain obvious reasons why it might be advisable to cause freshmen to become thus acquainted
with the activities scene. We also held off because we
were assured and reassured that once and for all, assembly debates were to be ended by the Council-Extra Council committee. And so, in our infinite patience we waited,
Now, one month after the formation of the committee, only John Higham and Charles Flagle of the
group have met together for discussion. Hardly a

way to settle what has been deemed a problem pressing enough to be planked in each platform. Hardly
the question which rolled up a signed petition with
hundreds of names two years ago.
Why doesn't the Council get moving? Are class
elections so engrossing as to occupy all of the Council's time? Last year it was the Council's action of
the first month which provoked a furor noisy to Hoboken and back. This year the Council has trouble
getting all its men out to a meeting. Well, if the assembly problem is so important in the Council's opinion, why not turn it over to someone or some group
who are willing and anxious to work on it. If not,
merely abide by last year's promises and drop the
whole matter.
We think there is some reasonable answer to the
whole problem, and one not too taking of the mind.
Either have infrequent, absorbingly interesting assemblies ,open to all classes non-compulsorily; or else have
compulsory assemblies for freshmen only. But if the
Council decides on the latter course, it takes upon itself the responsibility for making assemblies important
enough to freshmen to warrant their making them
compulsory. Freshmen, we are certain, do not want
to be entertained against their wills. They do not
resent as greatly being educated or enlightened in that
way. But movies on the steel industry, or even Captain Bob Bartlett ,interesting as he was, do not appear
worthy of forced attendance.
We started out to take the Council to task. It's a
shame to have to do it so early in the year, but we
firmly believe that we're justified, and members of the
Council have agreed with us. Along the line we've
dropped a few suggestions, which may or may not be
of value. At any rate, if delay is extended much longer
the problem will solve itself for this year at least.
There will be no time left for assemblies!
There is more interest on
the campus now on the subject of a literary magazine
than we have detected in a
four year stay. Projects developed at the end of last
year seem to have dropped
for various and sundry reasons during the summer
and since, but the interest and sentiment has been
sustained. However, no organized effort appears to
be forthcoming.

Pi D E,
Blue Jay:
An Old Story

Pi Delta Epsilon, the dormant journalistic honorary on the campus, has followed its usual policy of
recent years in regard to things journalistic: "Say
nothing, do nothing, never meet, drink beer." There
doesn't seem to be much use in trying to stir a dead
dog to life, so we suggest that interested men organize
themselves into a group through the English department.
There is only one ball and chain. There are too
many still on the campus who remember the old halfcaste Blue Jay. We refer to nothing of that sort. The
record of the old book should not be held against any
new venture. A new magazine would be a recognized
campus activity, with the finest which the campus has
to offer in the way of material.
Finances offer no problem. Magazine advertising
is plentiful and pays large dividends. In fact, we have
been assured by parties in the know that there should
be enough profit each year to enable the University to
establish a scholarship from the proceeds.
There is a definite place for a literary magazine on
the Hopkins campus. It could be distributed as the
NEWS-LETTER is. Students desire it and are interested
in it. What's holding us back?

The idea stems from one
of our editors who is feeling the tug of Indian Summer at his heart-strings. It
seems that there's a young
lady at Fensal hall . . .
which brings us once again
to the pleasant subject of our sisters down the street.

Girls,
Girls,
Girls

Let's start from scratch by commending the editors
of the Freshman handbook for their final corrections
of the telephone numbers of Goucher halls. It is
an incomparable service, rivaled only by the Chesapeake and Potomac 'phone book, and one serving to
alleviate the strain on already over-taxed ingenuities.
Second, we beg to submit, most humbly, our compliments to the freshman class at Goucher. Truly, a
bevy of gracious ladies to compliment a beautiful host.
Whither we are tending is beyond us. There is a
saturation point of beauty to which we are rapidly
approaching.
Fair ladies, we doff our chapeaux and spread our
robes. Mishandle not our hearts.

A Le Roy Swerdloff
NBC introduced two new sustaining programs last Tuesday. Now
who's going to sustain NBC?
The first program at 9.30, a literary
show under the direction of the editor
of the Atlantic Monthly entitled.
Meet Mr Weeks,—once you have you
won't for weeks.
An hour later, "For He's a Jolly
Good Fellow" heralded Mort Lewis's
new show, Fun With The Famous.
His last porgram was If I Had The
Chance; NBC gave him one, now he's
asking for another.
Mr Weeks read several famous
letters by Keats, Lincoln, Steele (of
Spectator fame) and Captain Scott;
but none could compare with the
letter a negro, who was to be executed, scribbled to the governor. It
read—"Dear Governor, On Friday
they hangs me and here it is Tuesday."
The first program is for the literati; the second is for that other class
of people.

Movie of the week
The Baltimore Symphony orchestra
plans a worthy series of three concerts to give Baltimoreans the possibilty of enjoying good symphonic
music early in the season. The younger members of the orchestra will
comprise a group of 41 instruments,
wind and string. They will play
classical and modern compositions of
various nations.
The first concert of three scheduled will be held at the Auditorium
theatre October 22. The other two
will follow provided sufficient support has been given for the initial
effort.
University students are asked to
support the project. Tickets are available at Albaugh's ticket agency at
$1.00, $.75 and $.50.

The strangest material pipssession
of the French, besides their famed
Maginot line, is their Frakish revelation into the mysteries of gracious

THE VODER, nicknamed Pedro, is an amazing electrical device which actually talks—the first machine
•
in the world to do that!
By pressing keys,singly or in combination,a skilled
operator can make Pedro talk in almost human fashion—with varying inflections and in either a man's or
a woman's voice.
The Yoder is an outgrowth of fundamental research
in speech sounds, articulation and voice reproduction
being carried on at Bell Telephone Laboratories. Such
studies have led— and will lead—to constantly improving telephone service for you.

A telephone call home would be appreciated. Rates to most points are lowest
any time after 7 P.M. and all day Sunday.

International relations

club plans symposium
A plan for a Peace Symposium was disclosed by the International
Relations club in its meeting last Tuesday at four o'clock in Levering hall.
The purpose of the Peace Symposium is to gather together, under the sponsorship of the International Relations club, some of the foremost authorities on international relations to discuss the various aspects of a program
for peace after this war. The plan has already been approved by President Bowman, and the date for the discussion has been set for December 2.
Professor Greenfield of the history department will be the chairman in
charge, and the following is' a tentative outline of the topic as it will be
discussed:
I. Stabilization
a Military b Ethnic c Economic
II. Theoretical Approaches
a Battle of Ideologies
b Liberty vs Authority
c U S of Europe
d International Law
e National vs International
Stabilization as a basis for peace.
The speakers to discuss these various divisions have not yet been decided upon, but a few of the possible
selections are: Harold Moulton, Pres
of Brookings Institutution; Raymond
Buell, former director of Geneva Research Bureau; Frederick Dunn, professor of international relations at
Yale; and Col Lawrence Martin,
chief of the map division of the Library of Congress.
The problem of peace, chosen by
the International Relations club for
its Symposium topic, is the most
pressing concern of the day, and
in which everyone is, by necessity,
interested.
Those who are particularly intriguthe subjects of peace and war and
and want to delve more deeply into it,
besides hearing the lectures, can
attend next Tuesday's meeting of the
International Relations club ,which
will welcome interested freshmen and
upperclassmen.

Taking their cue from Canada Dry,
the undergraduates at Goucher are
having an 'Information Please' quiz
to find out just how much some of the
teachers at their institution really
know. This is a repeat performance,
and will take place in Katherine
Hooper hall, St Paul and 24th Sts,
October 24 at 8:15 pm.
Deeming it essential to have a few
worldly males present, so that the
two faced cracks will be dully appreciated, those men of the Hopkins
student body who are interested are
cordially invited to attend.
Clifton Faddiman, the able dispenser of questions and puns, will be
aped by Dr C I Winslow. The Board
of experts will consist of Drs Ivan
McDougal, Eugene Custis, Huntley
Lloyd, Annette Hopkins, and Mary
Andrews. This imposing group will
be grilled by the students through
Dr Winslow. All questions will be
submitted by the students.
Last year, when the program was
first given, it was a huge success.
There were many hilarious incidents,
'and the whole performance was so
well received that this encore is by
popular demand. Highlights of last
year's show included Dr McDougal's
vocal rendition of 'Hold Tight', and
his explanation of a wimple. Another
notable incident was Dr Curtis'
demonstration of a hustle.
Well, fellows, here's your chance
to give the girls down the street the
once over, without having to be stuck
for a full evening. Also, they'll be
there en masse, and you can see all
for the price of one. The premium is
two-bits, and tickets may be procured at the gate.

A FRENZIED bellowing as of a
gored ox, has burst forth in the letters column. Two communications,
each wordier than the original argument, have been evoked by a simple
statement of the following facts: (1)
It's a wicked world. (2) In all probability the United States will go to
war before you an I are too old to
fight (about 1965). (3) The collegetrained citizen is a special beneficiary
of American society, and should
therefore develop his unusual talents
and opportunities so that he may
give more than the police-enforced
minimum of military service when
this society is endangered. (4) Acquisition of a reserve commission
after training in the ROTC is the
proper means of performing this
duty.
IN ANSWER, Mr "TWM" attaches
to me the statement that war is in
some way desirable for its own sake.
this imputation is false, and known
to him as false; undoubtedly he had
my column before his eyes as he
manufactured this calculated misrepresentation. The rest of his yawp
said only that he doesn't like war—
not a novel or rare idea. He was not
direct enough to stand for abject
fight-for-nothing pacifism, although
that is obviously the only tenable alternative to the principle of national
and personal preparedness. He only
says "I'm not interested in bombs"
—an excellent epitaph for the citizenry of Canton, Warsaw, and perhaps, soon, London, perhaps, later,

even FOR HIM.
AN HONEST misunderstanding
seems to befuddle Mr Oppenheimer.
The necessity of ready force for the
success of any policy is not, I hope,
an eternal principle. It is, however,
an unavoidable reality during this
long chaotic night, when peace is
dead, and mighty states are making
up their international law as they go
along. When nations act in humane
amity and not in hate or fear, we may
disarm; but futile weakness today
does not hasten the coming of such a
tomorrow. Instead, a comparatively
rich and disarmed state in a society
of the strong and hungry Is only a
provocation and a prey to the agAs Solon said to Croesus
gressor.
t,
"Sir, if any man come who has better
iron than you, he will be master of
all this gold."
YOU can judge all such problems
for yourself. I ask only that they be
judged logically, in accordance not
with our temptations toward ease,
inertia, or hysteria, but with the superior responsibility of the collegetrained citizen. One of the letters
was no more intellectual or convincing than a razzberry; the other cannot possibly be called a systematic
attack. A surprisingly large proportion of the verbiage was strictly
through the fedora. I hope that you
other students who disagree with my
essay will formulate a logical basis
for your opinion and compare your
arguments point by point with mine
before irrevocably closing your minds.

'Hullabaloo' staff
to start subscription

The drive for 100 per cent senior
subscription to the Hullabaloo for
1940 will start rolling on Monday,
when every senior will be approached
by a staff member.
According to Alan M. Hecht, senior
editor, " it is an absolute necessity
that we get complete Senior support
this year, so as to enable us to produce a yearbook worthy of the class
of 1940. The Hullabaloo is a publication mainly for the senior class, and
therefore if the seniors want a lasting memory of their college days it
is up to them to give the Hullabaloo
complete cooperation."
Assignments for write-ups were
given out yesterday at the weekly
staff meeting. Work on the book is
already under way, and it will probably appear several weeks earlier
than in previous years. Individual
photographs of fraternity members
will be eliminated, and group frat
photos will take their place. This
move it is hoped, will obviate much of
the confusion that featured the picture-taking of last year's book, and
thus make possible a smoother production schedule.
Jay students wishing to work on
the staff have an opportunity this
year. There are many vacant spots
to be filled, those desirious of trying
out should come to the office in the
basement of Levering hall any day.

The NEWS-LETTER wants another columnist. Since Buddy
Macht left last year, taking his
Pot Pourri with him, there' been
nothing like it in the paper.
Buddy's column had a touch of
philosophy and more than a little
humor and criticism; but above
all it rested on personality. He
included anything he thought

his dog, got twice as much space

out right.
If you think you can write
such a column, get in touch with

Big doings come from the BSA

Foremost among the bands contacted

Donahue's orchestra, currently featured in the Rainbow room.

last year as they contacted all the
bands who could possibly be obtained.

movie houses are at present bidding

week and will have a voice in the
selection of the Thanksgiving band.

reported by Kirkwood as a "financial

The second sex discussion in which
Goucher college and Hopkins' students will participate will be held at

Mrs Grace Sloan Overton's lecture
of last week. Bill Hammaker will be

aspects of sex relations.

Preparation for Marriage." "Wistful
sophistication is a term which may
be applied very aptly to our •present
generation," stated Mrs. Overton. Her
general theme was romantic love and
what it implies in conduct.

Students expecting to apply for
admission to any medical college by
next fall must take the medical
college aptitude test, the Registrar's
office announced recently.
This examination has been adopted
by the American association of Medical school as a means of determining
whether or not a student is qualified
to continue in medicine, and a passing mark is prerequisite to entrance
in a medical course. The test is designed to measure the student's ability to learn, his scientific background
and present store of information.
Also tested is the accuracy with
which the applicant can draw conclusions from a set of given data.
Application to take the exam must
be made immediately at room 18,
Remsen hall. The test will be given
for only this year on November
28 at 3:00 p m, in Remsen 101. A
fee of one dollar will be charged for
the examination.

At 8:15 last Monday evening, Rev
Dr Maurice S Sheehy, head of the
department of Religious Education,
Catholic University of America, gave
the first of a series of lectures on the
theme "Points of Difference Between
My Group and Others." ,Dr Sheehy
pointed out the main distinguishing
features of the Catholic doctrine, and
went on to explain a few of the major
problems which his church is facing
at present.

Petronian doctrines, the church has
an international untiy on an authoritarian basis.
However, the system of administration does not preclude a certain
plasticity of views, contrary to common belief.

Trustees to act on Shriver,
Vincent bequests Monday
Vincent
Exact terms of the will of Dr John
Martin Vincent, professor in the
social science department for 35
years and professor emeritus of that
department for 14 years, were received by the university last Monday.
Although the definite value of the
portion of the estate willed to the
university is, as yet, undetermined,
it is expected to yield $1,000,000. The
remainder of the estate has been
left by the late Dr Vincent to his
relatives and friends.
Dr Vincent's donation is the largest
ever received by a social science
department.
The bequest has been made to the
university without any legal demands
upon its disbursement. However, it
was the wish of Dr Vincent, according to his will, that the money be
used in the history department.
Members of the Board of Trustees
will meet Monday in one of their
three annual meetings. It is expected
that a decision will be reached at this
meeting as to the use of the bequest.

Shriver
Action on the Alfred Jenkins
Shriver bequest for the establishment
of a lecture hall with murals of the
Shriver family and Baltimore beauties will be taken Monday at the
meeting of the Board of Trustees, it
has been announced.
Although the exact amount of the
bequest is not known, an estimate
places the amount the Hopkins will
receive at approximately $650,000.
Under the donor's provisions, however, if the Board does not decide
within a six months period, the sum
will be offered in turn to Loyola and
Goucher.
The need for more elaborate lecture facilities has been emphasized
by the inconveniences accompanying
the talks of recent speakers here.
This need was especially felt at
the first of Dr James T Shotwell's
addresses at the Myer Katz Memorial Lectures. Because of the large
attendance, latecomers were forced
to stand outside the doors in Latrobe
hall, unable to hear.

FRIDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1939

It's pleasant to be able to
do other than criticize the
Barnstormers for a change.
We're never really had anything against the greasepaint lads, but matters of
policy and misunderstanding have often been bones of contention between us.
However, it looks as though there's s9mething really
swell in the offing.

We Take
It All
Back

First, the Club plans two productions this year—
although, they hasten to assure us, the idea is all
theirs, completely original. Second, it appears that
the Club has sure-pop, can't-miss irons in the fire, inthe form of two original or semi-original student (at
last!) plays.
We were highly flattered in being invited to the
preview of the first the other night. Frankly, we left
highly excited. We're not sure as to how much we're
at liberty to divulge; suffice to say that the play is a
hybrid original-rewrite by the Messrs Agrin and Victaroff of an exciting old. theme.
As we were told, a play depends on either dialogue
or action for effect. Since the 'Stormers themselves
(with our heartiest concurrence) admit a dearth of
material to carry the former, they've concentrated on
action. And there's action a-plenty.
Our contention has always been that the Hopkins
wants one of two things from the Club—a rollicking,
slapsticky farce, or a good student play. The subject
matter of the latter is unimportant—the vital thing is
that if it is from a student ,and is good, it will engross
students. And, assuming that the 'Stormers are anxious to gain campus goodwill, they would adhere to
these precepts and abstain from selfish half-baked
flings at art. Well, the play seems to fit the qualifications of our good student play.
We understand farther that our own "Toy" Swerdloff has submitted a slaphappy college farce which is
being considered for a second show. It never rains
but it pours! Should this go through, the Club will
be giving the campus the biggest time any of us here
now can remember.
Maybe we're a little premature with all this, but
we feel like saying right now, "Come back home,
boys, all is forgiven!"
In May, 1939 the Hopkins student body tramped
to the polls and elected a
Student council pledged by
platform (except for those
few who deemed posting
of platforms beneath them
—and got away with it) to abolish compulsory assemblies. At the beginning of October 1939, the
Council held its first assembly—compulsory. An assembly committee was set up to investigate and settle
the problem once and for all. And now at the end
of October we're back where we were in February 1939.
Time marches back!

Same
Old
Stalemate

We refrained from editorial comment on the first
compulsory assembly at the time because we thought
there were certain obvious reasons why it might be advisable to cause freshmen to become thus acquainted
with the activities scene. We also held off because we
were assured and reassured that once and for all, assembly debates were to be ended by the Council-Extra Council committee. And so, in our infinite patience we waited,
Now, one month after the formation of the committee, only John Higham and Charles Flagle of the
group have met together for discussion. Hardly a

way to settle what has been deemed a problem pressing enough to be planked in each platform. Hardly
the question which rolled up a signed petition with
hundreds of names two years ago.
Why doesn't the Council get moving? Are class
elections so engrossing as to occupy all of the Council's time? Last year it was the Council's action of
the first month which provoked a furor noisy to Hoboken and back. This year the Council has trouble
getting all its men out to a meeting. Well, if the assembly problem is so important in the Council's opinion, why not turn it over to someone or some group
who are willing and anxious to work on it. If not,
merely abide by last year's promises and drop the
whole matter.
We think there is some reasonable answer to the
whole problem, and one not too taking of the mind.
Either have infrequent, absorbingly interesting assemblies ,open to all classes non-compulsorily; or else have
compulsory assemblies for freshmen only. But if the
Council decides on the latter course, it takes upon itself the responsibility for making assemblies important
enough to freshmen to warrant their making them
compulsory. Freshmen, we are certain, do not want
to be entertained against their wills. They do not
resent as greatly being educated or enlightened in that
way. But movies on the steel industry, or even Captain Bob Bartlett ,interesting as he was, do not appear
worthy of forced attendance.
We started out to take the Council to task. It's a
shame to have to do it so early in the year, but we
firmly believe that we're justified, and members of the
Council have agreed with us. Along the line we've
dropped a few suggestions, which may or may not be
of value. At any rate, if delay is extended much longer
the problem will solve itself for this year at least.
There will be no time left for assemblies!
There is more interest on
the campus now on the subject of a literary magazine
than we have detected in a
four year stay. Projects developed at the end of last
year seem to have dropped
for various and sundry reasons during the summer
and since, but the interest and sentiment has been
sustained. However, no organized effort appears to
be forthcoming.

Pi D E,
Blue Jay:
An Old Story

Pi Delta Epsilon, the dormant journalistic honorary on the campus, has followed its usual policy of
recent years in regard to things journalistic: "Say
nothing, do nothing, never meet, drink beer." There
doesn't seem to be much use in trying to stir a dead
dog to life, so we suggest that interested men organize
themselves into a group through the English department.
There is only one ball and chain. There are too
many still on the campus who remember the old halfcaste Blue Jay. We refer to nothing of that sort. The
record of the old book should not be held against any
new venture. A new magazine would be a recognized
campus activity, with the finest which the campus has
to offer in the way of material.
Finances offer no problem. Magazine advertising
is plentiful and pays large dividends. In fact, we have
been assured by parties in the know that there should
be enough profit each year to enable the University to
establish a scholarship from the proceeds.
There is a definite place for a literary magazine on
the Hopkins campus. It could be distributed as the
NEWS-LETTER is. Students desire it and are interested
in it. What's holding us back?

The idea stems from one
of our editors who is feeling the tug of Indian Summer at his heart-strings. It
seems that there's a young
lady at Fensal hall . . .
which brings us once again
to the pleasant subject of our sisters down the street.

Girls,
Girls,
Girls

Let's start from scratch by commending the editors
of the Freshman handbook for their final corrections
of the telephone numbers of Goucher halls. It is
an incomparable service, rivaled only by the Chesapeake and Potomac 'phone book, and one serving to
alleviate the strain on already over-taxed ingenuities.
Second, we beg to submit, most humbly, our compliments to the freshman class at Goucher. Truly, a
bevy of gracious ladies to compliment a beautiful host.
Whither we are tending is beyond us. There is a
saturation point of beauty to which we are rapidly
approaching.
Fair ladies, we doff our chapeaux and spread our
robes. Mishandle not our hearts.

The Baltimore Symphony orchestra
plans a worthy series of three concerts to give Baltimoreans the possibilty of enjoying good symphonic
music early in the season. The younger members of the orchestra will

wind and string. They will play
classical and modern compositions of
various nations.

theatre October 22. The other two

University students are asked to
support the project. Tickets are available at Albaugh's ticket agency at
$1.00, $.75 and $.50.

The strangest material pipssession
of the French, besides their famed
Maginot line, is their Frakish revelation into the mysteries of gracious

long before Henry VIII, on the other
side of Le Manch threw turkey
drumsticks at his wives.

THE VODER, nicknamed Pedro, is an amazing electrical device which actually talks—the first machine
•
in the world to do that!
By pressing keys,singly or in combination,a skilled
operator can make Pedro talk in almost human fashion—with varying inflections and in either a man's or
a woman's voice.
The Yoder is an outgrowth of fundamental research
in speech sounds, articulation and voice reproduction
being carried on at Bell Telephone Laboratories. Such
studies have led— and will lead—to constantly improving telephone service for you.

A telephone call home would be appreciated. Rates to most points are lowest
any time after 7 P.M. and all day Sunday.

In order to weed out poor material
and to uncover every bit of talent in
Hopkins for next spring's tennis
team, Joel Jaffe, the manager, is
running a tennis tournament.

seem to be the best men participating. Since these two meet in a first
round match, the winner should advance far in the tournament. Other
stand outs are P Stern, H Coulsen,
and E Lamed.
Several preliminary and first round
matches have been completed. When
the first day's contests had been completed J Delk had swamped S Wolfe,
6-1, 6-2, B Rubenstein had out served
S Naron 7-5, 6-3, M Goldsmith had

Weiss had beaten C Kleinberg 7-5,
6-2. Darkness halted the BaratzChekett match after the first set. The
latter led, 7-5.

are capable of inter-collegiate competition. After having completed one

maintain their high standard of play

International relations

club plans symposium
A plan for a Peace Symposium was disclosed by the International
Relations club in its meeting last Tuesday at four o'clock in Levering hall.
The purpose of the Peace Symposium is to gather together, under the sponsorship of the International Relations club, some of the foremost authorities on international relations to discuss the various aspects of a program
for peace after this war. The plan has already been approved by President Bowman, and the date for the discussion has been set for December 2.
Professor Greenfield of the history department will be the chairman in
charge, and the following is' a tentative outline of the topic as it will be
discussed:
I. Stabilization
a Military b Ethnic c Economic
II. Theoretical Approaches
a Battle of Ideologies
b Liberty vs Authority
c U S of Europe
d International Law
e National vs International
Stabilization as a basis for peace.
The speakers to discuss these various divisions have not yet been decided upon, but a few of the possible
selections are: Harold Moulton, Pres
of Brookings Institutution; Raymond
Buell, former director of Geneva Research Bureau; Frederick Dunn, professor of international relations at
Yale; and Col Lawrence Martin,
chief of the map division of the Library of Congress.
The problem of peace, chosen by
the International Relations club for
its Symposium topic, is the most
pressing concern of the day, and
in which everyone is, by necessity,
interested.
Those who are particularly intriguthe subjects of peace and war and
and want to delve more deeply into it,
besides hearing the lectures, can
attend next Tuesday's meeting of the
International Relations club ,which
will welcome interested freshmen and
upperclassmen.

away or have artificial barriers, armament. Being good alone is hard
work."

Taking their cue from Canada Dry,
the undergraduates at Goucher are
having an 'Information Please' quiz
to find out just how much some of the
teachers at their institution really
know. This is a repeat performance,
and will take place in Katherine
Hooper hall, St Paul and 24th Sts,
October 24 at 8:15 pm.
Deeming it essential to have a few
worldly males present, so that the
two faced cracks will be dully appreciated, those men of the Hopkins
student body who are interested are
cordially invited to attend.
Clifton Faddiman, the able dispenser of questions and puns, will be
aped by Dr C I Winslow. The Board
of experts will consist of Drs Ivan
McDougal, Eugene Custis, Huntley
Lloyd, Annette Hopkins, and Mary
Andrews. This imposing group will
be grilled by the students through
Dr Winslow. All questions will be
submitted by the students.
Last year, when the program was
first given, it was a huge success.
There were many hilarious incidents,
'and the whole performance was so
well received that this encore is by
popular demand. Highlights of last
year's show included Dr McDougal's
vocal rendition of 'Hold Tight', and
his explanation of a wimple. Another
notable incident was Dr Curtis'
demonstration of a hustle.
Well, fellows, here's your chance
to give the girls down the street the
once over, without having to be stuck
for a full evening. Also, they'll be
there en masse, and you can see all
for the price of one. The premium is
two-bits, and tickets may be procured at the gate.

A FRENZIED bellowing as of a
gored ox, has burst forth in the letters column. Two communications,
each wordier than the original argument, have been evoked by a simple
statement of the following facts: (1)
It's a wicked world. (2) In all probability the United States will go to
war before you an I are too old to
fight (about 1965). (3) The collegetrained citizen is a special beneficiary
of American society, and should
therefore develop his unusual talents
and opportunities so that he may
give more than the police-enforced
minimum of military service when
this society is endangered. (4) Acquisition of a reserve commission
after training in the ROTC is the
proper means of performing this
duty.
IN ANSWER, Mr "TWM" attaches
to me the statement that war is in
some way desirable for its own sake.
this imputation is false, and known
to him as false; undoubtedly he had
my column before his eyes as he
manufactured this calculated misrepresentation. The rest of his yawp
said only that he doesn't like war—
not a novel or rare idea. He was not
direct enough to stand for abject
fight-for-nothing pacifism, although
that is obviously the only tenable alternative to the principle of national
and personal preparedness. He only
says "I'm not interested in bombs"
—an excellent epitaph for the citizenry of Canton, Warsaw, and perhaps, soon, London, perhaps, later,

even FOR HIM.
AN HONEST misunderstanding
seems to befuddle Mr Oppenheimer.
The necessity of ready force for the
success of any policy is not, I hope,
an eternal principle. It is, however,
an unavoidable reality during this
long chaotic night, when peace is
dead, and mighty states are making
up their international law as they go
along. When nations act in humane
amity and not in hate or fear, we may
disarm; but futile weakness today
does not hasten the coming of such a
tomorrow. Instead, a comparatively
rich and disarmed state in a society
of the strong and hungry Is only a
provocation and a prey to the agAs Solon said to Croesus
gressor.
t,
"Sir, if any man come who has better
iron than you, he will be master of
all this gold."
YOU can judge all such problems
for yourself. I ask only that they be
judged logically, in accordance not
with our temptations toward ease,
inertia, or hysteria, but with the superior responsibility of the collegetrained citizen. One of the letters
was no more intellectual or convincing than a razzberry; the other cannot possibly be called a systematic
attack. A surprisingly large proportion of the verbiage was strictly
through the fedora. I hope that you
other students who disagree with my
essay will formulate a logical basis
for your opinion and compare your
arguments point by point with mine
before irrevocably closing your minds.

—Religion—
(Continued from Page 1, Col. 1)
Despite authoritarian theological
government, the Catholic church
fights Communism and Fascism as
representative of state regimentation.
Among the problems confronting
the Church of today, Dr Sheehy pronounced one to be "the danger of its
entanglement with politics." He made
no specific references to cases in
which this is occurring.
Dr Sheehy's lecture is the first of a
series of three which will be given on
this theme. At the completion of the
series the speakers will return for
three more lectures based on questions which their listeners are requested to hand in to them. Each
Monday night, at 120 Latrobe hall
the speakers will point out the differences between the three great
Western religious. Next Monday Dr
Samuel McRea Cavert, secretary of
the Federal council of Churches of
Christ in America, will explain the
Protestant viewpoint. The following
week Rabbi James G Heller of Cincinnati. Ohio will speak for the Jewish religion.
